newsitem.title: FINLAND: UPM LWC news signals turnaround - analysts.
newsitem.headline: UPM LWC news signals turnaround - analysts.

text.p: Finnish forest industry group UPM-Kymmene's announcement that it will raise prices of light-weight coated paper signals an earlier than expected turnaround in product prices, industry analysts said on Tuesday.
"We expected price hikes at the earliest in the summer -- this is a really positive surprise," said Jaakko Niemela, chief analyst at Opstock.
"We have now seen the bottom of the price cycle in LWC," he added.
UPM-Kymmene -- the world's leading manufacturer of coated magazine paper -- said on Tuesday it will raise prices of LWC paper by 5-8 percent during the first quarter of 1997.
LWC paper is used for magazines and direct mail order catalogues, among others.
Last year, the price of LWC paper fell about 20 percent and it has been over 18 months since UPM announced any price hikes in LWC, analysts said.
Brisker than forecast economic growth in UPM's main markets such as the United Kingdom and the Benelux countries has clearly boosted demand for paper, they said.
"Positive economic growth has created demand for paper," said Jukka Huuskonen, senior investment analyst at Arctos Securities.
"And demand has clearly surpassed expectations," he added.
UPM's share jumped 1.50 markka to 99.00 on the news, pulling the whole sector sub-index up 1.38 percent. Turnover in UPM's shares was lively at over 16 million markka.
Analysts saw scope for further gains in UPM and other forestry shares, providing that the price increases hold and that there will more increases down the line.
"I expect the stock to gain about 10-20 percent in the near-term," said one analyst requesting anonymity.
Another Finnish forest industry group, Metsa-Serla Oy, said on Monday that prices of coated papers had turned into a rise but that prices of other paper grades were still in decline.
